questions.question_text: Lines of latitude on Earth run east–west and measure angular distance __________.
options: from the Earth's center to the surface
north or south of the Equator
east or west of the Prime Meridian
questions.correct_answer: north or south of the Equator

questions.question_text: Lines of longitude on Earth run north–south and measure angular distance __________.
options: north or south of the Equator
from the Earth's center to the surface
east or west of the Prime Meridian
questions.correct_answer: east or west of the Prime Meridian

questions.question_text: What is the latitude of the Earth's North Pole?
questions.correct_answer: 90° North

questions.question_text: The Prime Meridian, the zero degree line of longitude, passes through which location?
questions.correct_answer: Greenwich, England

questions.question_text: Which geometrical shape best represents the Earth for navigation purposes?
questions.correct_answer: An oblate spheroid (ellipsoid)

questions.question_text: The Earth's rotational axis passes through the __________.
options: geographic North Pole and geographic South Pole
magnetic North Pole and magnetic South Pole
geographic North Pole and magnetic South Pole
questions.correct_answer: geographic North Pole and geographic South Pole

questions.question_text: The shortest distance between two points on the Earth’s surface is along __________.
options: a line of latitude (except the Equator)
questions.correct_answer: a great circle route

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a great circle on the Earth?
questions.correct_answer: The Equator

questions.question_text: A rhumb line is a line on the Earth's surface that __________.
options: represents the shortest path between two points
is a line of constant latitude
crosses all meridians at the same angle (constant heading)
questions.correct_answer: crosses all meridians at the same angle (constant heading)

questions.question_text: The approximate circumference of the Earth at the Equator is __________.
One degree of latitude corresponds to roughly what distance on the Earth’s surface?
questions.correct_answer: 60 nautical miles

questions.question_text: One minute of latitude (1') is approximately equal to __________.
questions.correct_answer: 1 nautical mile

questions.question_text: The Arctic Circle is located at approximately __________.
questions.correct_answer: 66.5° North latitude

questions.question_text: Magnetic variation is defined as the angle between __________.
options: true north and magnetic north at a given location
an aircraft’s heading and true north
questions.correct_answer: true north and magnetic north at a given location

questions.question_text: Compass deviation is the angle between __________.
options: the aircraft’s heading and true course
the aircraft’s heading and magnetic north
questions.correct_answer: magnetic north and compass north

questions.question_text: An isogonic (isogonal) line on a map connects points of equal __________.
questions.correct_answer: magnetic variation

questions.question_text: An agonic line is a line on Earth along which __________.
questions.correct_answer: variation of 0°

questions.question_text: One nautical mile is defined as exactly __________.
questions.correct_answer: 1852 meters

questions.question_text: A 'knot' is a unit of speed equal to __________.
questions.correct_answer: one nautical mile per hour

questions.question_text: Which units are officially used for horizontal distances in aviation?
questions.correct_answer: Nautical miles (NM) and kilometers (km)

questions.question_text: In aviation weather and navigation, a wind direction given as 090° means the wind is coming from the __________.
questions.correct_answer: east (blowing toward the west)

questions.question_text: “VOR” is an acronym that stands for __________.
questions.correct_answer: Very High Frequency Omnidirectional Range

questions.question_text: “NDB” in navigation stands for __________.
questions.correct_answer: Non-Directional Beacon

questions.question_text: “DME” is a navigation aid acronym. What does DME stand for?
questions.correct_answer: Distance Measuring Equipment

questions.question_text: “GPS” in the context of aviation navigation stands for __________.
questions.correct_answer: Global Positioning System

questions.question_text: “ADF” is the instrument that points to an NDB station. ADF stands for __________.
questions.correct_answer: Automatic Direction Finder

questions.question_text: A VOR radial is defined as __________.
options: the magnetic bearing extending outward from the VOR station
the route directly to the station
any line of position drawn on a chart
the true bearing of the station from the aircraft
questions.correct_answer: the magnetic bearing extending outward from the VOR station

questions.question_text: What information does an ADF indicator provide the pilot?
options: The relative direction (bearing) of the NDB station from the aircraft’s nose
The distance to the NDB station
The aircraft’s heading relative to true north
The magnetic course to fly to the station (without wind)
questions.correct_answer: The relative direction (bearing) of the NDB station from the aircraft’s nose

questions.question_text: Navigating by visual reference to landmarks (e.g. following roads or rivers) is called __________.
questions.correct_answer: pilotage

questions.question_text: Navigating by calculating distance and direction from a known point, using time, speed, and heading (with wind), is known as __________.
questions.correct_answer: dead reckoning

questions.question_text: Which ground features are most useful for visual (pilotage) navigation under VFR?
options: Prominent features like rivers, highways, and railroad tracks
questions.correct_answer: Prominent features like rivers, highways, and railroad tracks

questions.question_text: If your true course is 090° and the variation is 10°E, what is the magnetic course?
Electronic devices and metal components in an aircraft can cause errors in the magnetic compass known as __________.
questions.correct_answer: deviation

questions.question_text: If an altimeter is set to QFE (airfield pressure) and you land back at that airfield, the altimeter will read approximately __________.
options: the field elevation above sea level
questions.correct_answer: 0 feet (field elevation above that field)

questions.question_text: Flying from a region of high pressure into a region of lower pressure without resetting the altimeter will result in the aircraft being __________ than indicated.
options: lower (at a lower true altitude than the altimeter indicates)
questions.correct_answer: lower (at a lower true altitude than the altimeter indicates)

questions.question_text: At a ground speed of 90 knots, how long will it take to fly a distance of 45 NM?
questions.correct_answer: 30 minutes

questions.question_text: An aircraft travels 100 kilometers in 56 minutes. What is its average ground speed in km/h (approximately)?
questions.correct_answer: 107 km/h

questions.question_text: If an aircraft’s magnetic heading is 130° and the compass deviation is 5°W, what compass heading will the pilot see?
Under Visual Flight Rules (VFR) cruising altitude rules in the Northern Hemisphere, on a magnetic course of 090° (eastbound above 3,000 ft AGL) a pilot should fly at __________.
options: an odd thousand-foot altitude plus 500 feet (e.g., 5,500 ft)
an even thousand-foot altitude plus 500 feet (e.g., 4,500 ft)
questions.correct_answer: an odd thousand-foot altitude plus 500 feet (e.g., 5,500 ft)

questions.question_text: How many GPS satellites are normally needed to obtain an accurate three-dimensional position fix (latitude, longitude, and altitude)?
questions.correct_answer: Four

questions.question_text: What navigation information does a conventional VOR (without DME) provide?
options: Your bearing to/from the station (direction), but not distance
Ground speed relative to the station
Both direction and distance to the station
The exact distance to the station
questions.correct_answer: Your bearing to/from the station (direction), but not distance

questions.question_text: What does Distance Measuring Equipment (DME) provide to a pilot?
options: The slant range distance to the DME station (in nautical miles)
The magnetic bearing to the station
The wind correction angle to maintain course
questions.correct_answer: The slant range distance to the DME station (in nautical miles)

questions.question_text: If a pilot keeps the ADF needle centered (pointing to 0°) without correcting for wind, the aircraft will __________.
options: follow a curved path to the station (i.e., homing with drift)
maintain a straight track to the station even in a crosswind
fly a great circle route automatically
remain exactly on the intended course
questions.correct_answer: follow a curved path to the station (i.e., homing with drift)

questions.question_text: Which is an advantage of VOR (VHF) navigation compared to NDB (LF) navigation?
options: VOR signals are less susceptible to static interference and night effects than NDB signals
VOR signals follow the curvature of the Earth beyond the horizon
VOR provides distance information without additional equipment
VOR receivers do not require line-of-sight to the station
questions.correct_answer: VOR signals are less susceptible to static interference and night effects than NDB signals

questions.question_text: What should a pilot always do before using a VOR for navigation?
options: Listen to the station’s Morse code identifier to verify the correct station and that it’s functioning
Ensure the OBS is set to 000°
Request clearance from ATC to use the VOR
Turn the aircraft to face the station
questions.correct_answer: Listen to the station’s Morse code identifier to verify the correct station and that it’s functioning

questions.question_text: What typically happens when you pass directly over a VOR station?
options: The VOR indicator will temporarily fluctuate or show no valid signal (the TO/FROM flag may switch)
The CDI will remain perfectly centered
The VOR’s Morse code identifier will speed up
You will get an immediate DME distance of zero
questions.correct_answer: The VOR indicator will temporarily fluctuate or show no valid signal (the TO/FROM flag may switch)

questions.question_text: The range at which you can receive a VOR signal depends largely on __________.
questions.correct_answer: the aircraft’s altitude (line-of-sight range)

questions.question_text: According to the “1-in-60 rule,” 1° of tracking error will result in about 1 NM off course after _____ NM.
If you discover you are 3 NM off course after flying 30 NM, approximately what total heading correction should you make to intercept the original track by 60 NM (destination)?
options: About 12° toward the course (double the 6° error)
questions.correct_answer: About 12° toward the course (double the 6° error)

questions.question_text: In the Northern Hemisphere, when turning right from a heading of north, a magnetic compass will initially __________.
options: lag behind the actual turn (indicate a left turn or turn slower than reality)
temporarily freeze until the turn is complete
lead the turn (indicate a faster or greater turn)
questions.correct_answer: lag behind the actual turn (indicate a left turn or turn slower than reality)

questions.question_text: If your aircraft consumes 8 gallons of fuel per hour, how much fuel is required for a flight of 2 hours 30 minutes, plus a 45-minute reserve?
questions.correct_answer: approx. 24 gallons

questions.question_text: How does a headwind or tailwind affect your ground speed?
options: A headwind decreases ground speed, and a tailwind increases ground speed.
Wind has no effect on ground speed, only airspeed.
A headwind increases ground speed, and a tailwind decreases ground speed.
Both headwind and tailwind increase ground speed.
questions.correct_answer: A headwind decreases ground speed, and a tailwind increases ground speed.

questions.question_text: You land at 17:30 local time (UTC+5). What time (UTC) should you enter in your logbook for the landing?
To convert a true course into a compass heading, which sequence of corrections is applied?
options: Add or subtract variation to get magnetic course, then add or subtract deviation to get compass heading.
Subtract deviation from true course directly.
Correct for wind, then add variation only.
questions.correct_answer: Add or subtract variation to get magnetic course, then add or subtract deviation to get compass heading.

questions.question_text: On VFR aeronautical charts, large bold numbers (e.g., 25) in each quadrangle represent __________.
options: the Maximum Elevation Figure (MEF), the highest terrain or obstacle elevation (MSL) in that area
the distance in nautical miles across that section of the chart
the minimum safe altitude for that area in hundreds of feet
questions.correct_answer: the Maximum Elevation Figure (MEF), the highest terrain or obstacle elevation (MSL) in that area

questions.question_text: Obstacle elevations on sectional charts are often given with two numbers, e.g., “1540 (1450)”. The number in parentheses is the __________.
options: height of the obstacle above ground level (AGL)
height of the obstacle above mean sea level (MSL)
distance of the obstacle from a nearby airport
required circling altitude near that obstacle
questions.correct_answer: height of the obstacle above ground level (AGL)

questions.question_text: A chart with a scale of 1:250,000 will show __________ compared to a chart of 1:1,000,000.
options: a smaller area with more detail (larger scale map)
a larger area with less detail
the same area but with different units
a larger area with more detail
questions.correct_answer: a smaller area with more detail (larger scale map)

questions.question_text: On a 1:500,000 scale aeronautical chart, 1 centimeter on the chart corresponds to about __________ on the ground.
questions.correct_answer: 5 kilometers

questions.question_text: Which is true regarding a Mercator projection chart used for navigation?
options: Rhumb lines appear as straight lines, while great circles appear as curved lines, and scale increases with latitude.
Scale is uniform everywhere on the chart.
Great circle routes are straight lines on a Mercator chart.
questions.correct_answer: Rhumb lines appear as straight lines, while great circles appear as curved lines, and scale increases with latitude.

questions.question_text: Which statement is correct about a Lambert Conformal Conic projection chart?
options: It is a conformal map (preserves shape) and is nearly true to scale (minimal distortion).
It is an equal-area projection (preserves area).
Meridians are parallel on the chart.
Great circles appear as large curves and rhumb lines as straight.
questions.correct_answer: It is a conformal map (preserves shape) and is nearly true to scale (minimal distortion).

questions.question_text: “ILS” is a system commonly used for precision approaches. What does ILS stand for?
questions.correct_answer: Instrument Landing System

questions.question_text: The localizer component of an ILS provides __________ guidance to the runway.
questions.correct_answer: horizontal (left/right)

questions.question_text: True Airspeed (TAS) is the aircraft’s speed through the air, while Ground Speed (GS) is the speed __________.
options: over the ground (TAS adjusted for wind)
through still air with no wind
questions.correct_answer: over the ground (TAS adjusted for wind)

questions.question_text: The difference between an aircraft’s heading and its actual track over the ground is known as the __________.
questions.correct_answer: drift angle (caused by wind)

questions.question_text: If you are flying east and a wind is blowing from the south, the aircraft will drift __________.
options: to the north of the intended track
to the south of the intended track
questions.correct_answer: to the north of the intended track

questions.question_text: Why must the directional gyro (heading indicator) in an aircraft be periodically realigned with the magnetic compass?
options: Because the gyro will drift over time due to precession, causing heading errors
To correct for magnetic variation automatically
Because the compass rotates the card automatically
It does not need to be realigned once airborne
questions.correct_answer: Because the gyro will drift over time due to precession, causing heading errors

questions.question_text: How can a pilot find the magnetic variation to use for flight planning along a route?
options: By consulting the isogonic lines (lines of equal variation) printed on the aeronautical chart for that area.
It is the same everywhere, given in the aircraft manual.
By checking the compass deviation card.
Variation is negligible and usually ignored.
questions.correct_answer: By consulting the isogonic lines (lines of equal variation) printed on the aeronautical chart for that area.

questions.question_text: On a colder than standard day, how will your altimeter reading compare to your true altitude?
options: The altimeter will read higher than the true altitude (you are lower than indicated).
The altimeter will read lower than true altitude.
It will be exact if QNH is set.
Temperature does not affect altimeter readings.
questions.correct_answer: The altimeter will read higher than the true altitude (you are lower than indicated).

questions.question_text: Pressure altitude is the altitude read on the altimeter when __________.
options: the altimeter is set to the standard pressure setting (29.92" Hg or 1013 hPa)
the altimeter is set to the local QNH
the instrument is at sea level under standard conditions
questions.correct_answer: the altimeter is set to the standard pressure setting (29.92" Hg or 1013 hPa)

questions.question_text: At the magnetic equator (roughly halfway between the magnetic poles), the inclination (dip) of Earth’s magnetic field is approximately __________.
questions.correct_answer: zero (the magnetic field is horizontal)

questions.question_text: In aviation weather reports (METARs), wind directions are given relative to __________.
questions.correct_answer: true north

questions.question_text: At latitude 60°N, one degree of longitude spans approximately how far on the ground?
questions.correct_answer: 30 NM

questions.question_text: If you are on the 090° radial of a VOR and you want to fly directly to the station, you should steer a course of approximately __________.
questions.correct_answer: 270° (i.e., fly west toward the station)

questions.question_text: On a VOR indicator, what does the TO/FROM flag tell you?
options: Whether your selected course would take you to the station or away from it
How far off course you are in degrees
The quality of the signal reception
If you are north or south of the station
questions.correct_answer: Whether your selected course would take you to the station or away from it

questions.question_text: On a standard VOR CDI (Course Deviation Indicator), each dot of deflection from center represents about __________ off course.
questions.correct_answer: 2° of angular deviation

questions.question_text: On topographic maps or aeronautical charts, very closely spaced contour lines indicate __________.
questions.correct_answer: steep terrain (rapid elevation change)

questions.question_text: On U.S. sectional charts, airports with control towers are depicted in __________, whereas airports without towers are in __________.
questions.correct_answer: blue; magenta

questions.question_text: A star (*) or asterisk next to an airport’s name on a sectional chart indicates the airport has __________.
options: a rotating beacon (usually from sunset to sunrise)
questions.correct_answer: a rotating beacon (usually from sunset to sunrise)

questions.question_text: VFR Sectional charts in the United States are commonly drawn at a scale of __________.
The compass rose depicted around a VOR station on aeronautical charts is aligned to __________.
options: magnetic north (so the radials are magnetic bearings)
questions.correct_answer: magnetic north (so the radials are magnetic bearings)

questions.question_text: Around noon in the Northern Hemisphere, if you are facing the sun directly, you are generally facing __________.
questions.correct_answer: south

questions.question_text: QNH is the altimeter setting that causes the altimeter to read __________.
options: elevation (height above mean sea level) when on the ground at that location
questions.correct_answer: elevation (height above mean sea level) when on the ground at that location

questions.question_text: QFE is the pressure setting that will make the altimeter read __________ when the aircraft is on that reference datum (e.g., on the runway).
questions.correct_answer: zero

questions.question_text: QNE refers to the standard altimeter setting of 1013 hPa (29.92" Hg). At and above the transition altitude, pilots set QNE and fly at __________.
questions.correct_answer: flight levels

questions.question_text: “Flight Level 85” (FL085) corresponds to __________ on the altimeter with standard setting.
questions.correct_answer: 8,500 feet (pressure altitude on 1013 hPa)

questions.question_text: To determine your position, you tune and identify two VORs and note you are on the 210° radial of one and the 120° radial of another. You plot those on your chart. Your position is at the __________.
questions.correct_answer: intersection of the two radials

questions.question_text: If you have a VOR/DME station, what information can you obtain with suitable equipment?
options: Both direction (bearing) to/from the station and distance (slant range)
questions.correct_answer: Both direction (bearing) to/from the station and distance (slant range)

questions.question_text: “WCA” in navigation stands for __________.
questions.correct_answer: Wind Correction Angle

questions.question_text: Absolute altitude is defined as the aircraft’s height __________.
questions.correct_answer: above the surface (AGL)

questions.question_text: True altitude is the aircraft’s height __________.
options: indicated on the altimeter with 1013 set
above the standard datum plane (pressure altitude)
questions.correct_answer: above mean sea level (MSL)

questions.question_text: If your magnetic heading is 350° while your true heading is 340°, what is the magnetic variation in that area (assuming negligible wind and deviation)?
questions.correct_answer: 10° West

questions.question_text: Compass deviation of 3° East means the compass needle __________.
options: needs 3° added to compass heading to get magnetic heading
questions.correct_answer: points 3° east of magnetic north

questions.question_text: On aeronautical charts, bodies of water such as lakes and rivers are typically colored __________.
questions.correct_answer: blue

questions.question_text: On a sectional chart, green and brown color tints are used to depict __________.
options: different terrain elevations (green for lower elevations, brown for higher elevations)
land cover (green for forests, brown for deserts)
questions.correct_answer: different terrain elevations (green for lower elevations, brown for higher elevations)

questions.question_text: At night, NDB (ADF) navigation can be adversely affected by the ‘night effect,’ which is caused by __________.
options: ionospheric reflections of the radio waves after sunset, making the ADF needle erratic
questions.correct_answer: ionospheric reflections of the radio waves after sunset, making the ADF needle erratic

questions.question_text: A VORTAC is a navigation aid that combines __________.
options: a VOR and a TACAN station (providing VOR radials and DME distance)
two VOR stations in one unit
an onboard GPS with VOR capabilities
a VOR and an ADF in one facility
questions.correct_answer: a VOR and a TACAN station (providing VOR radials and DME distance)

questions.question_text: ETA vs ETE: ETA (Estimated Time of Arrival) is the clock time when you expect to arrive, whereas ETE (Estimated Time Enroute) is __________.
options: the expected duration of the flight (how long it will take)
the time you will spend on the ground
questions.correct_answer: the expected duration of the flight (how long it will take)

questions.question_text: The mnemonic “East is least, West is best” helps pilots remember how to apply __________.
options: magnetic variation (subtract East variation, add West variation to true course)
wind corrections (left for east wind, right for west wind)
questions.correct_answer: magnetic variation (subtract East variation, add West variation to true course)

questions.question_text: What is “RNAV” (Area Navigation)?
options: A method of navigation that allows direct flight on any desired course within coverage of navaids or satellites, by using waypoints
Navigation solely by reference to ground landmarks
questions.correct_answer: A method of navigation that allows direct flight on any desired course within coverage of navaids or satellites, by using waypoints

questions.question_text: Your aircraft burns 12 gallons of fuel per hour. How much fuel will be used on a 1.5 hour flight, plus a 45-minute reserve?
questions.correct_answer: approximately 26 gallons

questions.question_text: “Density altitude” is best described as __________.
options: pressure altitude corrected for non-standard temperature (the altitude in ISA that has the same air density as the current conditions)
height above the ground at a given temperature
the altitude read on the altimeter when set to 1013 hPa
the altitude indicated on the altimeter with QNH set
questions.correct_answer: pressure altitude corrected for non-standard temperature (the altitude in ISA that has the same air density as the current conditions)

questions.question_text: If you become lost or disoriented during flight, one recommended action is to “Climb.” Why is climbing useful when lost?
options: It increases radio and navaid reception range and extends your visual horizon to spot landmarks.
It makes the compass more accurate.
ATC requires climbing before declaring an emergency.
It guarantees you will find your position by reaching a VOR signal.
questions.correct_answer: It increases radio and navaid reception range and extends your visual horizon to spot landmarks.

questions.question_text: If you are lost and have a radio, what should you do after trying to locate yourself and if still uncertain?
options: Contact ATC or Flight Service on the radio and request assistance (confess you’re lost and ask for help).
Descend to try to read road signs or yell for help.
Turn 180° and go back the way you came without telling anyone.
Continue flying in a straight line until you recognize something.
questions.correct_answer: Contact ATC or Flight Service on the radio and request assistance (confess you’re lost and ask for help).

questions.question_text: You note that on a compass deviation card: “Magnetic Heading 120° = Compass reads 123°.” To fly a magnetic heading of 120°, you should steer a compass heading of __________.
Earth’s magnetic north pole is not fixed and not co-located with the geographic North Pole. In fact, the magnetic poles __________.
options: are exactly 180° apart from true poles
questions.correct_answer: drift over time

questions.question_text: An E6B (flight computer) is commonly used to __________.
options: perform navigation calculations (e.g., time, speed, distance, fuel, wind correction)
find the nearest airport in an emergency
questions.correct_answer: perform navigation calculations (e.g., time, speed, distance, fuel, wind correction)

questions.question_text: A plotter (navigation protractor) is used by pilots to __________.
options: measure course angles and distances on aeronautical charts
file a flight plan with ATC
questions.correct_answer: measure course angles and distances on aeronautical charts

questions.question_text: Which is longer: one nautical mile or one statute mile?
options: One statute mile (SM is longer than NM)
questions.correct_answer: One nautical mile (1 NM ≈ 1.15 SM)

questions.question_text: 100 miles per hour (statute) is approximately how many knots?
questions.correct_answer: about 87 knots

questions.question_text: Magnetic variation can change significantly over distance. On a long east–west flight, a pilot should __________.
options: update the variation value for each section of the route as shown on charts (it may not be constant)
use the departure airport’s variation for the whole flight
ignore variation changes if under 5° difference
rely on GPS to account for variation automatically
questions.correct_answer: update the variation value for each section of the route as shown on charts (it may not be constant)

questions.question_text: “Civil twilight” is defined as the period when the sun is less than _____ below the horizon (in the morning before sunrise, or evening after sunset).
“True course” (TC) is defined as the angle between __________ and the intended path of the aircraft over the ground.
options: true north and the course line (track) on the map
magnetic north and the course line
the aircraft’s longitudinal axis and a meridian
questions.correct_answer: true north and the course line (track) on the map

questions.question_text: “Magnetic course” (MC) is defined as the aircraft’s course relative to __________.
options: magnetic north (i.e., true course corrected for variation)
questions.correct_answer: magnetic north (i.e., true course corrected for variation)

questions.question_text: “UTC” (Coordinated Universal Time) is effectively the same as __________ time.
options: Greenwich Mean Time (GMT), the time at the Prime Meridian (0° longitude)
Standard time in your local zone
questions.correct_answer: Greenwich Mean Time (GMT), the time at the Prime Meridian (0° longitude)

questions.question_text: While flying directly toward a VOR station, you note the bearing to the station changes by 10° in 2 minutes. About how many minutes from the station are you?
options: Approximately 12 minutes (time to station ≈ (60 × minutes flown) / degrees change)
questions.correct_answer: Approximately 12 minutes (time to station ≈ (60 × minutes flown) / degrees change)

questions.question_text: In the Northern Hemisphere, when turning from a south heading, a magnetic compass will __________.
options: lead the turn (indicate a greater or faster turn than is actually occurring)
lag behind the turn (initially indicate opposite turn)
questions.correct_answer: lead the turn (indicate a greater or faster turn than is actually occurring)

questions.question_text: “Endurance” in flight planning refers to __________.
options: the maximum time an aircraft can stay airborne on the available fuel
the maximum distance an aircraft can fly on full fuel
the cruising speed of the aircraft
questions.correct_answer: the maximum time an aircraft can stay airborne on the available fuel

questions.question_text: How does a headwind or tailwind component affect an aircraft’s range (distance it can fly on a given amount of fuel)?
options: A headwind decreases range (ground distance) for the same fuel, whereas a tailwind increases range.
A tailwind decreases range because groundspeed is higher.
Wind does not affect range, only time aloft.
A headwind increases range because the aircraft flies slower relative to the ground.
questions.correct_answer: A headwind decreases range (ground distance) for the same fuel, whereas a tailwind increases range.

questions.question_text: To find your position using two VORs, you would __________.
options: tune each VOR, identify the radials you’re on from each station, and plot those radials on your chart; where they intersect is your position
fly directly over one VOR and measure the angle to the second
use one VOR radial and your DME distance from it
tune the closer VOR only, since the intersection method works with one station
questions.correct_answer: tune each VOR, identify the radials you’re on from each station, and plot those radials on your chart; where they intersect is your position

questions.question_text: With a VOR/DME station, a pilot can obtain __________.
options: both direction (bearing) to/from the station and distance (slant range)
questions.correct_answer: both direction (bearing) to/from the station and distance (slant range)

questions.question_text: “TAS” stands for __________.
questions.correct_answer: True Airspeed

questions.question_text: “IAS” is an acronym for __________.
questions.correct_answer: Indicated Airspeed

questions.question_text: In the Northern Hemisphere, the acronym “UNOS” helps remember compass turn errors: Undershoot North, __________.
questions.correct_answer: Overshoot South

questions.question_text: In compass terms, “ANDS” (Accelerate North, Decelerate South) describes the tendency of a compass on east or west headings to show a false turn toward __________ when accelerating.
options: the north (when accelerating) and toward the south when decelerating
the south (when accelerating) and north when decelerating
the east (regardless of acceleration or deceleration)
questions.correct_answer: the north (when accelerating) and toward the south when decelerating

questions.question_text: Unlike VOR signals (which are line-of-sight VHF), NDB signals in the LF/MF band can follow the curvature of the Earth (ground wave). At night, however, NDB signals can travel farther via skywaves, causing __________.
options: the NDB’s Morse code to change
questions.correct_answer: erratic ADF needle indications (night effect)

questions.question_text: On an aeronautical chart, “elevation” of a terrain point or airport means height above __________.
questions.correct_answer: mean sea level (MSL)

questions.question_text: In which frequency band do DME transmitters operate?
questions.correct_answer: UHF (ultra high frequency around 960 MHz)

questions.question_text: When you cross the International Date Line traveling eastbound (for example, from Asia to America), you should __________.
options: subtract one day from your calendar date
add one day to the date
set your clock forward by 12 hours
set your clock back by 12 hours
questions.correct_answer: subtract one day from your calendar date

questions.question_text: One meter is approximately equal to __________.
questions.correct_answer: 3.3 feet

questions.question_text: “Homing” to a radio beacon (such as an NDB) means __________.
options: flying toward the station by keeping the needle centered, without correcting for wind (resulting in a curved path)
using two beacons to triangulate position
flying a wind-corrected path to track directly to the station
flying an outbound course from the station
questions.correct_answer: flying toward the station by keeping the needle centered, without correcting for wind (resulting in a curved path)

questions.question_text: “Tracking” to a station means __________.
options: applying wind correction to fly a straight path to or from the station
following the needle without wind correction
using GPS rather than ground-based navaids
questions.correct_answer: applying wind correction to fly a straight path to or from the station

questions.question_text: One characteristic of a great circle route (other than the Equator) is that __________.
options: the direction (true heading) to follow changes gradually as you proceed along the route
it crosses all meridians at the same angle
it results in a constant compass heading
it is longer than a rhumb line between the same points
questions.correct_answer: the direction (true heading) to follow changes gradually as you proceed along the route

questions.question_text: A rhumb line route is often slightly longer than a great circle route, but it has the advantage that __________.
options: the heading remains constant (crosses each meridian at the same angle)
it is the absolute shortest distance
variation is zero along a rhumb line
questions.correct_answer: the heading remains constant (crosses each meridian at the same angle)

questions.question_text: Runway numbers (e.g., 18 or 36) are determined by the runway’s __________.
options: magnetic heading (approximate, in tens of degrees)
questions.correct_answer: magnetic heading (approximate, in tens of degrees)

questions.question_text: Your aircraft has 10 gallons of fuel remaining. You burn 5 gallons per hour. To preserve a 30-minute reserve, about how many more minutes can you fly?
questions.correct_answer: Approximately 90 minutes

questions.question_text: You have 100 liters of fuel onboard and your consumption is 20 L/hour. You plan to hold 30 minutes of reserve. How long (total) can you fly (approximately)?
questions.correct_answer: About 4.5 hours

questions.question_text: An aircraft flies 100 NM out and 100 NM back with a headwind one way and an equal tailwind returning. Compared to still-air, the total round-trip time will be __________.
options: longer (headwind/tailwind combinations increase total time compared to no wind)
questions.correct_answer: longer (headwind/tailwind combinations increase total time compared to no wind)

questions.question_text: If you fly directly over a DME station at 6,000 feet AGL, what will the DME read (approximately)?
options: About 1.0 NM (slant range equals altitude in NM)
0.0 NM (zero, because you are over the station)
questions.correct_answer: About 1.0 NM (slant range equals altitude in NM)

questions.question_text: In the Northern Hemisphere, if you accelerate on an east or west heading, a magnetic compass will initially indicate a turn toward __________.
options: the north (ANDS – Accelerate North, Decelerate South)
questions.correct_answer: the north (ANDS – Accelerate North, Decelerate South)

questions.question_text: You can also fix your position by using two different types of navigation aids. For example, using a VOR radial from one station and an ADF bearing from an NDB, you can plot lines and find your location at their __________.
questions.correct_answer: intersection

questions.question_text: Determining your position by advancing a previous known position using course, time, and speed (without new references) is called __________.
questions.correct_answer: dead reckoning

questions.question_text: If the magnetic heading is 350° and deviation is 2°E, what compass heading will you steer?
If the magnetic course is 200° and variation is 10°W, what is the true course?
Your compass indicates a heading of 100°. The deviation on that heading is 3°W. What is the magnetic heading?
You wish to fly a true heading of 090°. The variation is 5°E. What magnetic heading should you fly (ignoring wind and deviation)?
After a 100 NM flight leg, you find you are 10 NM off course. Approximately how many degrees were you off course (using the 1-in-60 rule)?
If you are significantly off course and only half the distance to go remains, a good rule of thumb to regain your track by the destination is to __________.
options: triple the drift correction (aim back toward the course by about three times the off-course angle)
cut the drift correction in half
questions.correct_answer: triple the drift correction (aim back toward the course by about three times the off-course angle)

questions.question_text: The term “track made good” refers to __________.
options: the actual path the aircraft travels over the ground
the heading you maintained during the flight
questions.correct_answer: the actual path the aircraft travels over the ground

questions.question_text: What is the difference between “bearing” and “heading”?
options: Bearing is the direction from the aircraft to an object/station, while heading is the direction the aircraft is pointed.
Heading is always magnetic; bearing is always true.
They are the same – both refer to where the nose is pointed.
Bearing accounts for wind, heading does not.
questions.correct_answer: Bearing is the direction from the aircraft to an object/station, while heading is the direction the aircraft is pointed.

questions.question_text: “Relative bearing,” as used with the ADF, means __________.
options: the angle between the aircraft’s nose/heading and the direction of the station (measured clockwise from the nose).
the compass bearing to the station from true north.
the difference between magnetic and true bearing.
the aircraft’s bank angle during a turn.
questions.correct_answer: the angle between the aircraft’s nose/heading and the direction of the station (measured clockwise from the nose).

questions.question_text: The groundspeed readout on a DME is accurate only when __________.
options: the aircraft is flying directly to or from the DME station (i.e., the distance to station is changing directly)
the aircraft is abeam the station
at any time, since DME computes GS independently of direction
questions.correct_answer: the aircraft is flying directly to or from the DME station (i.e., the distance to station is changing directly)

questions.question_text: How can you tell when you have passed directly over an NDB station using an ADF?
options: The ADF needle will swing rapidly through 180°, indicating the station is now behind you.
You cannot tell without a DME.
The ADF will lose its signal completely.
The ADF needle will point straight up (0°) continuously.
questions.correct_answer: The ADF needle will swing rapidly through 180°, indicating the station is now behind you.

questions.question_text: When passing directly over a VOR station, the TO/FROM indicator will __________.
options: swap indication (e.g., TO changes to FROM) as you go through the station
questions.correct_answer: swap indication (e.g., TO changes to FROM) as you go through the station

questions.question_text: In the standard atmosphere, for each 1,000 feet of altitude, true airspeed is roughly __________ indicated airspeed (assuming the same power setting).
questions.correct_answer: 2% higher than

questions.question_text: How does high humidity affect aircraft performance and density altitude?
options: High humidity decreases performance by effectively increasing density altitude (less dense air).
High humidity makes air more dense, improving lift.
High humidity increases engine power output.
Humidity has no effect on performance.
questions.correct_answer: High humidity decreases performance by effectively increasing density altitude (less dense air).

questions.question_text: When using GPS for navigation under VFR, a prudent pilot should __________.
options: maintain alternative navigation methods (e.g., charts and visual checkpoints) in case of GPS outage or error
turn off other navaids to avoid interference
fly solely by the GPS moving map, as it’s always correct
ignore NOTAMs about satellite outages as they are rare
questions.correct_answer: maintain alternative navigation methods (e.g., charts and visual checkpoints) in case of GPS outage or error

questions.question_text: “GLONASS” is __________.
options: a satellite-based navigation system operated by Russia (similar to GPS)
an old term for LORAN signals
questions.correct_answer: a satellite-based navigation system operated by Russia (similar to GPS)

questions.question_text: “Galileo” in the context of navigation refers to __________.
options: the European Union’s satellite navigation system
questions.correct_answer: the European Union’s satellite navigation system

questions.question_text: “GNSS” stands for __________.
options: Global Navigation Satellite System (a general term for satellite nav systems like GPS, GLONASS, etc.)
questions.correct_answer: Global Navigation Satellite System (a general term for satellite nav systems like GPS, GLONASS, etc.)

questions.question_text: If it is 12:00 UTC, what is the local time in a zone designated UTC+5:30?
If a pilot finds that a true heading of 100° results in a magnetic heading of 110° (with no wind), the variation in that area is __________.
questions.correct_answer: 10° West

questions.question_text: “QDM” is a term used in radio navigation that signifies __________.
options: the magnetic bearing (course) to fly *to* a station (from the aircraft to the station)
the magnetic bearing from the station (radial)
questions.correct_answer: the magnetic bearing (course) to fly *to* a station (from the aircraft to the station)

questions.question_text: “QDR” refers to __________.
options: the magnetic bearing *from* the station to the aircraft (the station’s radial to the aircraft)
a magnetic course to the destination
questions.correct_answer: the magnetic bearing *from* the station to the aircraft (the station’s radial to the aircraft)

questions.question_text: What is the difference between an NDB and an ADF?
options: The NDB is the ground transmitter beacon; the ADF is the aircraft’s receiver/instrument that points to it.
There is no difference—both terms describe the cockpit instrument.
ADF is a type of VOR station, NDB is not.
An NDB provides distance information, an ADF does not.
questions.correct_answer: The NDB is the ground transmitter beacon; the ADF is the aircraft’s receiver/instrument that points to it.

questions.question_text: How many radials does a VOR have?
questions.correct_answer: 360 radials (one for each degree)

questions.question_text: Modern VOR receivers are typically accurate to within about __________.
questions.correct_answer: ±1–2° of the actual bearing

questions.question_text: Approximately how far apart are meridians (lines of longitude) at latitude 30°N?
questions.correct_answer: 52 NM per degree

questions.question_text: If the wind is blowing from your left, will you drift left or right of your intended track (assuming you don’t correct)?
options: You will drift to the right of course (downwind).
You will drift to the left of course.
You won’t drift at all if heading is correct.
questions.correct_answer: You will drift to the right of course (downwind).

questions.question_text: The “five C’s” (Climb, Confess, Communicate, Conserve, and Comply) are commonly taught as steps to take when __________.
options: a pilot becomes lost or disoriented in flight
questions.correct_answer: a pilot becomes lost or disoriented in flight

questions.question_text: The wind triangle is a graphical method used in navigation to determine __________.
options: the effect of wind on heading and groundspeed (relationship between true course, wind, and true heading/groundspeed)
questions.correct_answer: the effect of wind on heading and groundspeed (relationship between true course, wind, and true heading/groundspeed)

questions.question_text: Standard sea level pressure and temperature in the International Standard Atmosphere (ISA) are __________.
If your true course is 100°, the wind correction angle is 5° to the right, and variation is 10°W, what magnetic heading should you fly?
You plan to fly a true course of 075°. Variation at your location is 5°E, and your compass deviation is 2°E. With no wind, what compass heading should you steer?
“RAIM” (Receiver Autonomous Integrity Monitoring) is a feature of GPS receivers that __________.
options: checks the consistency/accuracy of satellite signals to ensure reliable navigation
alerts ATC of your position automatically
augments GPS with ground signals for better accuracy
questions.correct_answer: checks the consistency/accuracy of satellite signals to ensure reliable navigation

questions.question_text: If flying eastward and the wind is blowing from the north, to maintain your course you should steer somewhat __________.
options: to the left (north of east, into the wind)
questions.correct_answer: to the left (north of east, into the wind)

questions.question_text: At 120 knots true airspeed, how much fuel will be consumed to fly 100 NM if your fuel burn is 8 GPH?
questions.correct_answer: About 6.7 gallons

questions.question_text: At a true airspeed of 120 knots, how far will you travel in 15 minutes?
questions.correct_answer: 30 NM

questions.question_text: An aircraft travels 240 NM in 2 hours. What is its average ground speed?
questions.correct_answer: 120 knots

questions.question_text: How long will it take to fly 50 NM at a ground speed of 100 knots?
questions.correct_answer: 0.5 hour (30 minutes)

questions.question_text: If it takes 3 hours to fly 360 NM, what is the aircraft’s ground speed?
questions.correct_answer: 120 knots

questions.question_text: When performing a VOR receiver ground check, the maximum permissible error is __________.
During an airborne VOR check (or dual VOR cross-check), the bearing error must not exceed __________ to be within acceptable limits.
A Terminal VOR (TVOR) typically has a service range of about __________.
questions.correct_answer: 25 NM radius (at appropriate altitudes)

questions.question_text: A VOT (VOR Test Facility) is used to __________.
options: test and calibrate VOR receivers on the ground (typically provides 360° FROM / 180° TO indication)
provide VOR signals in remote areas
broadcast weather information over VOR frequencies
questions.correct_answer: test and calibrate VOR receivers on the ground (typically provides 360° FROM / 180° TO indication)

questions.question_text: In the United States, the transition altitude (the altitude at or below which pilots set local altimeter, and above which standard pressure is used) is __________.
questions.correct_answer: 18,000 feet MSL

questions.question_text: What is the standard temperature lapse rate in the lower atmosphere?
options: Approximately 2°C per 1000 ft of altitude gain
questions.correct_answer: Approximately 2°C per 1000 ft of altitude gain

questions.question_text: The ILS glideslope provides a vertical descent path usually of about __________.
questions.correct_answer: 3° (3 degrees above horizontal)

questions.question_text: The ILS localizer signal is normally adjusted so that its full width is about __________ (full deflection covers this angle).
questions.correct_answer: 5° (approximately 2.5° on either side of centerline)

questions.question_text: Which flight instruments rely on the pitot-static system?
options: Altimeter, airspeed indicator, and vertical speed indicator
questions.correct_answer: Altimeter, airspeed indicator, and vertical speed indicator

questions.question_text: Which instruments are gyroscope-based in a typical light aircraft?
options: Attitude indicator, heading (directional) gyro, and turn coordinator
questions.correct_answer: Attitude indicator, heading (directional) gyro, and turn coordinator

questions.question_text: LORAN was a long-range navigation system that has been __________.
options: phased out/obsolete in favor of GPS
required as backup in all aircraft
questions.correct_answer: phased out/obsolete in favor of GPS

questions.question_text: “WAAS” – the Wide Area Augmentation System – is used to __________.
options: improve GPS accuracy and integrity (by using ground reference stations and geostationary satellites)
provide an alternate to VOR navigation
questions.correct_answer: improve GPS accuracy and integrity (by using ground reference stations and geostationary satellites)

questions.question_text: 121.5 MHz is known as the __________.
questions.correct_answer: international aviation emergency/distress frequency

questions.question_text: If you become lost and contact ATC for help, some facilities can provide a 'DF steer', which means __________.
options: using Direction-Finding equipment to guide you (by having you transmit and then giving vectors to help you navigate)
negotiating with weather stations for updates
questions.correct_answer: using Direction-Finding equipment to guide you (by having you transmit and then giving vectors to help you navigate)

questions.question_text: On a VFR cross-country flight, it is wise to select prominent visual checkpoints along your route roughly every 10–15 minutes. The purpose of this is to __________.
options: verify your position regularly and ensure you are on course
fly lower at those points to check landmarks
questions.correct_answer: verify your position regularly and ensure you are on course

questions.question_text: “BeiDou” is the name of __________.
options: China’s satellite navigation system (similar to GPS)
an African radio navigation beacon network
questions.correct_answer: China’s satellite navigation system (similar to GPS)

questions.question_text: Magnetic dip (inclination) is __________.
options: the vertical angle of Earth’s magnetic field lines relative to the horizontal plane
the oscillation of the compass card in turbulence
the difference between true and magnetic north
compass deviation caused by the cockpit
questions.correct_answer: the vertical angle of Earth’s magnetic field lines relative to the horizontal plane

questions.question_text: Magnetic dip causes a magnetic compass in the Northern Hemisphere to __________.
options: be sluggish and prone to errors, especially when turning or accelerating
point toward true north instead of magnetic north
read accurately only at the equator
reverse its north and south seeking ends
questions.correct_answer: be sluggish and prone to errors, especially when turning or accelerating

questions.question_text: For VFR flights in the U.S., it’s required to have enough fuel to reach the destination and then fly for at least _____ minutes (by day) or _____ minutes (by night) at normal cruise speed.
One benefit of filing a VFR flight plan is that __________.
options: if you do not close the flight plan, authorities will initiate search and rescue for you shortly after your ETA
fuel at your destination is reserved
it guarantees ATC radar service throughout the flight
you can fly in Class A airspace with a VFR plan on file
questions.correct_answer: if you do not close the flight plan, authorities will initiate search and rescue for you shortly after your ETA
